history.content:
I think this is doable, but for the sake of your project group, I would definitely let your potential group know about your commute situation before committing to their group, as the dynamics of each group are different.

As for my group, we met heavily for the design phase (planning the design and writing the design doc). By heavily, I mean meeting everyday for the week before the design review (which, by the way, is with a TA, and attendance  is mandatory, so you'll need to make sure you can make it to those for each project). As for the implementation phase, we hardly met at all.

Meeting in person is much more important when planning the design, since it makes it easier to get everyone on the same page. Once the design is agreed upon and finalized, implementation is more a matter of following your design doc, changing design decisions as necessary, and debugging, which can be done remotely. Working remotely works for us because we plan the division of work ahead of time and communicate on our progress frequently. Also, we make heavy use of git, which makes integrating everyone's code something that can be easily managed remotely. But YMMV.

history.content:
Due to certain circumstances, I might have to live far away from Berkeley next year and commute to campus twice a week. For 162, I think I'd be able to keep up with lectures by watching current/past webcasts, but I was wondering if I could get some info from people who've taken the class on what the projects are like.

How often did your project group have to meet up in person vs. working remotely/individually? How many days a week did your project group have to meet up?

Thank you in advance!
